captions.text: So from our TL;DR last week when we talked about the ideal man
A lot of people have been asking what the ideal woman is like for Korea
Oh, I thought you were going to say "What's the ideal hamster"
I would prefer dwarf hamster because dwarf hamsters can live together in union
But it you have a normal hamster
Like a teddy bear hamster
And you put another hamster in there and they fight each other to the death
Martina knows this because she actually owned hamsters growing up
I think they're wonderful
Bear and Moca, R.I.P.
bought a little liquor for your homies
So, to answer your question about what the ideal woman is like in Korea
It's a very complicated process
If you remember last week, there was a whole list or requirements
when it comes to ideal woman in Korea
You have to be pretty.
So that's it for this week's TL;DR, if you have a question for next TL;DR
Leave your question in the comment section below.
I'm actually joking
There is a little bit more that we're going to say about this
Are we joking?
Are we, though?
Are we?
That's pretty much the main requirement that you need as a woman.
If you're pretty, then pretty much all the other requirements on the list aren't that important
So obviously, there are people in Korea that get married because they love each other genuinely
And they aren't looking at a lost of requirements or anything.
And a lot of men in Korea are looking for more than just prettiness when it comes to a girl
But when it comes to the general standard
Pretty much prettiness is the most important thing.
I mean, it's difficult to not say that for the rest of the world too.
I know, it's not like this is a Korea thing only!
Yeah and I know you guys aren't going to say something like...
I'm looking for someone who is kind, caring and super ugly.
I want someone whose teeth look like they chew bricks.
That's something that's really important to me.
BUT what we're getting at is that there is an undeniable logic
That comes to dating in Korea
outside of that whole realm of
"I'd like to fall in love with someone"
And this brings us back to the concept of
Sogaeting~
Sogaeting, man.
What is that all about?
Whoa, your Jamaican accent makes me cringe on the inside
I only had a couple of Jamaican friends...
I grew up with them.
You grew up with My Jamaican friends?
I grew up with every Jamaican person in North America.
Really? All of them?
They all lived in your neighborhood?
Word.
Then do your Jamaican accent if you're so good at it.
I won't bumbleclod do it.
Ok?
Ginger beer
Oh my God.... oh...
So in our last TL;DR on the ideal male type we mentioned Sogaeting
What is basically blind dating in Korea
And this isn't something that desperate sad people do.
This is a very normal part of Korean culture
From lots of age levels.
Like from your 20s up unto your 30s
Whatever.
That's a Very small margin!
From your 20s to your 30s
Because you are expected to be married by then.
So that's why...
If not, you failed your life.
well, SooZee told me there was a different thing, that's for meeting people that is Just for getting married
Wait, wait. I remember this.
It was like My Son! Maiseon? [S]Hot sun?
What's it called, SooZee?
Matseon.
See? Matseon.
You're like "This is for my son~"
You can say like Matseon.
Anyways, sogaeting.
Since sogaeting is such an important part of dating culture.
That whole idea of list of requirements to match somebody
Is something that's on the forefront of dating.
So then Why is it that Korean guys have a much shorter list of requirements when it comes to sogaeting?
Well men do have the ideal look type when it comes to prettiness
The bagel yo
oh yes, bagelyo
Does that mean my face is of the size of a bagel?
Exactly.
And you have a hole in the middle.
Oh my God. That is terrible now that I thought that over!
Get your mind out of the gutter, Missy!
Actually bagel is a condensed(compound) word of baeigeul meaning baby and gul for glamor
So bagel. Like a baby glamorous face.
Yes. Above baby face means cute and young, youthful looking
And the the glamorous doesn't necessarily mean
Beyonce~
It means more like a curvy, big boobidy body
I guess that kind of Does mean Beyonce.
And you should be sexy and feminine but also innocent and aegyo (cute)
Cute and sexy at the same time
I'm not too sure how those things come together.
You're like "Oppa, I'm scared and So glamorously confident!"
Ok, so you've got the looks out, but why is it that guys don't really care about that many other things?
So you've got to think of it this way:
A Korean guy has that pressure that he should attend a SKY university.
Which we talked about last week.
So he has to study his ass off through high-school
Which means no dating
Trust me on that. Our high school students in Korea...
They're REALLY studying
Hagwons, after school tutoring
you get into a SKY university. You're like "YES!"
And you're doing ok in SKY university
Which means that you're going to go on to get into a big company job
or government job
And you're going to be well off.
So in turn that means that if you Do have a future wife
she doesn't really have to have job
Because you're going to be guaranteed to get a well paying job
So she can be a stay-at-home mom or stay-at-home wife
Which is what a lot of Korean women wind up doing
So if you're going to be a stay-at-home mo once you get married
Then what does it matter what university you went to?
What does it matter what job that you have?
Because you're pretty much going to abandon that when you start taking care of your family at home.
That's right. And I mean, if you go to SKY university the whole point is to get you a better career
But if you're not going to have a career
Then it doesn't really matter that you attend a SKY university
So in turn the only thing that really matters is for you to be pretty
So that you could pass on good genes to your kids
It's kind of harsh. I know it's very old-fashioned, but that's pretty much the reason behind it.
Now here's the thing:
There Are some other things that they're looking for:
Obviously they don't want someone who they don't like what so ever
you should obviously like each other.
You're going have to get along well.
They're thinking about these kind of things.
But if they go to a SKY university, that means they are looking for someone who is either
at the same university or lower than them.
They don't want someone who is better educated and has a better job than them
And then they feel like they're not really oppas taking care of you
kind of just like "oh, my girlfriend makes more money than me and has a better job than me"
There's still that old-fashioned mentality of "the man is the one that takes care of the family
He is the breadwinner. While the mother stays home and takes care of all the kids"
Hey, remember that one year in Bucheon
When I was teaching in my 3rd year of teaching
And you were unemployed and stayed at home in your PJs
And worked on building the EYK website?
you know what that's called? That's called having a sugar momma
And it's Awesome!
It's great!
Strongly recommend it. Give it a shot if you can!
So the final thing we want to point out here is that
there are some women that Do want to keep their careers
And they want to keep working while they're married
The problem is that there still might be an old-fashioned mentality with your husband
which it's totally fine that you're working. It's great that you can have double income.
Of course, bring in more money if you're doing that, but...
You've still got to take care of the kids and make me dinner when I get home.
So the problem is that: do you really want to have a full-time job
AND come home and make full Korean suppers and also take care of the kids
and do cleaning in the house. While your husband just has his job.
That seems like a pretty bad deal.
Totally unfreakin fair
Now this is a very big topic and there's still a lot that we want to talk about.
We mention in our blogpost when it comes to gender and equality and the dynamics of a family.
So make sure you click on the link right here
if you want to read more about it.
So what do you guys think about all of this?
Is this something that's unique to Korean culture
Or is it something that you have experience in your culture as well?
Let us know in the comment section below.
So that's it for this week's TL;DR
If you have a question for next week's TL;DR
Leave your question in the comment section below.
Or check out the questions already asked
And if you like them, thumb them up to bring them to our attention.
And don't forget to subscribe for more TL;DRs
Where we teach you about the dynamics of marriage
The first important thing is that you have to make your own love language.
Ducky......... when are we going to go to get something to eat?
I think we're going to go after when we get to finish this.
And after....... [Martina... Are you trying to kill me? *giggle*]
This is actually how we talk to each other when we're off camera.
Like furbies.
I think this is the first time anyone has actually seen us talking like this.
Let's see if anyone can actually understand us

comments.text:
I've heard that South Korea has a negative population growth.  One of the 
lowest in the world.  If they have a strict immigration policy like Japan, 
then who is going to fill those jobs in the future?  I also assume they 
have a growing retirement population who collect a government pension. So 
they're going to need people to work and pay taxes in order to support the 
elderly population.  My point is, they're going to have to rely on women to 
fill those jobs.  This also means they have to abandon their patriarchal 
society in order for the country to stay competitive with the rest of the 
first world. ﻿
comments.author: sophomore90

comments.text: cool definition bro
comments.author: hubobubo

comments.text:
+hubobubo that's the precise definition of patriarchal. In fact is how 
western society was in .. idk 1950's? and that's what is called 
"patriarchal". You need to update on the correct definition. It is called 
like that because men get an education and monopoly over the money (since 
they are the ones earning it) and women are just mothers and maids. That's 
precisely the opposed to a more egalitarian society where any woman can 
have a career and and men can be a stay home dad if they wish (or the other 
way around or both can work or whatever) and no one gives a fuck about what 
men and women are "supposed" to do. Just do your thing whether you're a man 
or a woman
comments.author: haruno21

comments.text:

How is this a patriarchal system? Men are expected to work like dogs there

women. But it hardly sounds like a system set up for the express benefit of 
men and detriment of women.

comments.author: Anime Aires

comments.text:
+Bibimbapski Yes. I wish you and your nephew and niece luck!! I too will

comments.author: Anime Aires

comments.text:
+Anime Aires Yes it's good. I have a niece and nephew in university. 
They're both in SNU and their generation wants to change this. They're 
recognizing the deficiencies of this culture that puts too much emphasis on 
physical appearances and antiquated values that are unfair to both men and 
women, most especially the children. They're also going against the tide of 
overworking themselves, they're supporting a good work-life balance unlike 
the previous generation wherein there were cases of people who were so 
overworked they suffered, neglected their health and some would eventually 
die due to the stress and pressure. I'm glad that South Korea is slowly 
changing.
comments.author: Bibimbapski

comments.text:
+Bibimbapski omg. I didn't now it was that bad.... But I think that society 
is improving now days.
comments.author: Anime Aires

comments.text:
+UltimateBoo I grew up in both the States and Asia and divorce is pretty 
common in South Korea. Yes, South Korea is a conservative country but 
that's just a facade. Divorce is at an all time high there. Many people 
don't even want to get married much less have kids which is why it's 
impacting their population. I lived in South Korea for seven years, I 
attended a wedding there in 2002 and in 2005 the same couple divorced. Also 
remember that South Korea had the highest cases of SUICIDE due to their 
superficial and hypocritical society that puts too much emphasis on keeping 
up with said facade. You can't really be yourself or enjoy yourself unless 
other people approve of it. My nephew even contemplated suicide because of 
the pressure and his parents are still forcing him to study, study, study 
and discourage him from being himself. 


You know what's disgusting? Pressuring kids to study and ignore their 
dreams in favor of getting a stable job such as becoming a doctor, 
engineer, etc. Then after graduation, getting plastic surgery just so that 
you're guaranteed to get a job, to society to accept you and find you 
remotely attractive, to find a potential husband/wife and pump out kids who 
would likely go through the same bullshit you did. If that's not disgusting 
then you're pretty fucked up for thinking it's acceptable or others should 
understand it. Even Koreans know there's something wrong with this 
ingrained mentality.
comments.author: Bibimbapski

comments.text: +fedfoofy true, I guess. but I feel as if it's more dominant in Korea.
comments.author: Anime Aires

comments.text:
+Anime Aires Uh...just in Korea? I would say that's the case everywhere. 
It's human nature.
comments.author: fedfoofy

comments.text:
My family is asian. They have that mentality. Evryone should strive to make 
something out of their life but of course kids should come before that. 
Lots of ways to make it tho. People dont try enough. Society and family 
members need to go away and let the parents parent unless theyre abusing 
the kids or not giving attention. All societies are awful and asian ones 
are especially backwads
comments.author: Coco Pops

comments.text:
Well i wasn't talking about abuse. Because abuse is a no-no no matter where 
you're from. I think you're misinterpreting my arguments. & thats the 
mentally of westerners. asian parents don't give a crap about throwing 
their life away for their children. and if they do, society and their own 
family scolds them for it so there is no out. like i said, its more 
culturally oriented, it's probably something you don't understand unless 
you're from the mainland. gg
comments.author: UltimateBoo

comments.text:
Divorcing over stupid matters is dumb. I'm talking about abuse. Not stupid 
matters. Millions more would divorce. It just teaches that couples kids 
that the abusive parents actions are FINE. Your dreams and choices 
shouldn't disappear once kids come along. You need to keep yourself happy 
so you can do the same. Loving yourself first is what lets you love others. 
If you aren't healthy how will your kids be? Whatever. No use in arguing!
comments.author: Coco Pops

comments.text:
+Jéssica De Freitas Maciel when i said "together" i meant it in a sense 
where it doesn't matter if its good/bad or healthy/unhealthy... kind of 
like, "glued?". But yes, i agree that a happy healthy marriage is the 
preferred type of marriage in terms of their children's health. 
unfortunately, that doesn't usually happen especially in a conservative 
country like korea because there's this strong cultural bias against people 
that have divorced even if the divorce was better for the children. The 
reason why is because once a parent goes through a divorce, they can no 
longer see their children nor associate themselves with them of the male's 
line of family (usually & discriminately the mother). idk which is worse. 
but yes, i agree and understand that there isnt a perfect way. I was just 
stating how, particularly, korean society is with divorces.

@coco pops im pretty sure i offended someone *cough* by saying some things 
that they aren't familiar with... "disgusting mindset"... and im not sorry, 
its the internet.
comments.author: UltimateBoo

comments.text:
+UltimateBoo here's a reason why korea has extremely low divorce rates 
compared to the rest of the world. And whatever it is, its keeping families 
together, and not ruining their kid's lives. ﻿

That is debatable, i do think very highly of how much effort goes into 
making the marriage work and not easily giving up on it. But saying that a 
low divorce rate keeps families together (maybe in name yes, but in many 
cases not the way it matters) and doesn't ruin kids lives is a fallacy.
Yes in many cases it is true, but in equal or more cases still, it is very 
false. A happy, healthy couple is what makes healthy (mentally at least) 
kids and families.
So in those cases where the family is "together" merelly by societal 
imperatives, your phrase couldn't be more far from the truth. In fact, 
sometimes a non-traditional family where the couple is divorced may be 
better to the kids than seeing daily their sires fighting or ignoring each 
other.
I'm just saying, let's not get hot headed and generalize, not to one side, 
not to the other, what works and doesn't works is very particular to each 
person and couple. There isn't a perfect way, or a perfect culture, people 
or nation, everyone does the best they can with what they have.
comments.author: Jéssica De Freitas Maciel

comments.text: +UltimateBoo soo...fking... true...
comments.author: saehwa yim

comments.text:
+Coco Pops The stigma that comes with divorcing someone is natural. Much 
like how theres stereotypes for a person. You can't get rid of it. Why? 
because stigma is something that is observed and individually judged to 
make it generalized to be bad (in this case). I never said, kids will turn 
out to be bad if you divorce someone. Please read again. You cant be 
selfish and pretend your kids didnt happen, or neglect your parenthood 
duties to YOLO your own life. thats why most (if not all) parents from east 
asia (not sure about other countries) do not go through separation, 
regardless of what happens to them. Parenthood isnt something that is taken 
likely. Once you have children, your life, your desires, your dreams are 
all gone. Being raped of course,... is a different matter that isn't 
involved in this argument. Once you have children through marriage, you 
live for your kids. This is why the topic of marriage is an extremely 
important subject in asia moreso than the west and how people don't marry 
until their 30s compared to their worldly counterparts. There is even a 
current problem atm because of this. Most younger generations (under 40) 
are not having kids because of the heavy responsibility and sacrifice that 
comes attached to it, this is leading to a overpopulation of older 
people:younger people. This mentality is not just mine. This is how most of 
asians from the mainland think. And if you don't accept this, then you're 
better off living in the west. Of course there are extreme cases of abuse, 
which part of the worlddoesnt have this trait? but should it define 
marriage as a whole in asia? no. There are more abuse cases in asia than in 
their western counterpart because asia along with the middle-east are 
societies dominated by men. I'm not trying to be sexist or anything, but 
its a cultural thing that no one can change until the society gets more 
diverse (which is highly unlikely).
comments.author: UltimateBoo

comments.text:
+UltimateBoo Your mindset is so disgusting! That is why millions of 
domestic violence and rape cases aren't reported in asia. The backwards 
mindset where you should stay with someone for the kids. What if you are 
abused? Raped? You are fighting all the time? The people I meet who have 
divorced parents are perfectly FINE. They are happy they didn't end up like 
the kids whos parents didn't. Those kids aren't stupid. They know what 
happens in the parents lives and then start to become sad and it affects 
behaviour! 
Many in the east would divorce if it wasn't for the stigma still associated 
with it. They would report rape. A divorcee or single parent can provide 
more love separately than two people might.
People should not break up for small things like they do today however. I 
do know people who have mini arguments and then BOOM they are divorced. 
THAT is stupid. It is happening more often. Other than that cheating is a 
main cause. Should a person stay with a cheater? Even if they provide lots 
of money? Or will the person being cheated on have to be called a DOORMAT 
and GOLD DIGGER. Society has so many issues. Abuse of any kind shouldn't be 
tolerated. Good people deserve good people. just because someones eastern, 
it doesn't mean they are any better. Millions have skeletons in their 
closets as do people in other parts of the world.

comments.text:
I think the best relationships are the ones where, first and foremost, both 
partners are independent and happy with themselves (mental health and 
happiness is important) and when they come together, they are able to 
respect and love each other just the same, if not grow stronger together. 
If one partner feels that the other partner should not do what they want to 
do to feel happy and self-sufficient, then that really just relfects that 
one partner's insecurities and to be honest, that's really a big turn-off. 
That's not love in my opinion. I love it when I can admire someone and like 
them for who they are and they can do just the same for me. Love is about 
appreciation, not possession. I learned what not to do from my parent's 
relationship. ﻿
comments.author: Casandra Lopez

comments.text:
People who go to blind dating do not look for true love. What they want is

about the relationship ( But it's probably a right thing to do in Western

comments.author: UltimateBoo

comments.text:
+Casandra Lopez My relationship of 3+ years I feel is pretty solid. Both of 
us have mental issues, but our issues are ego-dystonic (meaning we can 
recognize them as issues, because they're not personality based). I agree 
that mental health is definitely important. For us, it's the only thing 
that we remotely have issues with. We've never faught, but it's pretty 
shitty to be depressed or cry or feel angry because of your issues that are 
so difficult to fix, as well as of course personal RL stuff that can 
happen. Both of us were ... well, fairly content being on our own. When we 
met, we were not looking for anyone and hadn't been for a while. Not to say 
that looking for someone is a bad thing, but you need to be at least 
relatively ok with your life and not expect your partner to fix it. A 
partner is like really awesome food. You need to be ok surviving on the 
basics, but once you have the really awesome food, you don't want to let it 
go. Kinda hard to explain, so I hope that made sense.Give and take, you 
both need to bring something to the relationship. And communication, that's 
pretty much the most important thing. If you're upset tell them, directly 
and talk it through. And they should show the same courtesy.My parents 
(I've actually disowned both of them) were the opposite of a good 
relationship, abuse, both have severe personality disorders, had a kid when 
they couldn't afford it ... aaaaand, married in 3 weeks of knowing each 
other .... yeah.

comments.text:
About military service and feminism: Until recently we also had obligatory 
military service in Sweden, but it was easy to avoid it (if you weren't in 
shape, you said you were depressed etc you didn't have to go through with 
it). Women could also join. My brother told me that half of the people who 
did the military service with him were women. He did his military service 
in Stockholm. He guarded the castle and he rode horses among many things. 
He was actually the only guy who was considered a good horseman so when the 
king and queen took tours around Stockholm in a carriage around special 
occasions he was the only one of hundred horse"men" who was a guy..the rest 
were women. Imagine that tourists in Sweden! ﻿

comments.author: HerpyDerpy

comments.text:
The many comments here regarding the roles of men and women primarily stem 
from a western focused ideology. 'Feminism' from the west is a foreign 
concept in a confucian based culture like Korea. For example, men in Korea 
are required to serve 21 to 24 months in the military with a compensation 
of less than $100 dollars per month. This service is generally unavoidable 
and occurs in the prime of ones life. The emphasis on roles and 
responsibilities in Korea are foundational to Korean society. As much as a 
woman in Korea may not reach a certain standard for a certain man, it is 
also greatly true that a particular man would not meet a certain standard 
for a woman in Korea~~i.e. he is not good looking enough, he is not tall 
enough, he doesn't earn enough money, etc. It is easy to look and judge 
Korea from a western perspective and judge it with what one knows. But, it 
is better to look more deeply and live amongst them for a while and 
understand intimately than it is to form biases based upon your own 
cultural norms.﻿

comments.text:
I come from a south asian background, pakistani-american to be exact, and 
the whole gender equality situation is pretty spot on. Especially back home 
the guys don't mind if the do get educated, but the women are expected to 
either drop their entire career to become a housewife, or do both at the 
same time. It's very conservative and very old fashioned but since I grew 
up in the states my way of thinking is also drastically different from what 
the average pakistani fob guy would want/expect  from me .-- There are some 
girls who don't really care if they even finish school or not because 
they're expected to get married early and take care of their husband and 
in-laws after marriage. Some of them don't mind at all but it's their 
choice and if that's what makes them happy then I think it's fine. Overall, 
there's a huge similarity and a lot of other countries are dealing with a 
similar issue. ﻿

comments.author: kuroichan101

comments.text:
+kuroichan101 Of course, women are able to be primary caregivers, that's 
what stay-at-home moms do. You need to do your research about Korea and not 
rely on internet memes because a lot of what you are saying is not grounded 
in facts. What jobs do they expect only women to have? Nursing? That does 
happen, but also in America.
comments.author: jstele

comments.text:
+jstele women are able to be primary caregivers too though and the kid will 
turn out fine. In korea some jobs they just expect only women to have and 
lots of women wont get promoted because of their gender or stay in 
administration, yes some of this does happen in america but korean sexism 
is a little more over the top and some of them act like its just an 
unspoken of rule
comments.author: kuroichan101

comments.text:
+kuroichan101 There are a lot of unfounded assumptions about Korea in your 
post. Is there sexism? Yes, but that happens even in Western countries. 
American women still aren't paid the same amount as the men. There are 
still statistics on this. As far as respect goes, that is arguable. I know 
that in Korea, men are expected to act more conservatively. You rarely see 
men catcalling women. That is considered low behavior. In some places in 
America, that is considered normal. There are special parking spaces for 
women in some areas of Korea that make it more convenient for them. In 
America, some people don't respect stay-at-home moms because they really 
think they are unfeminist or lazy. Is that respect? I don't think so.

Studies have shown that parents do best with a primary caregiver that is 
able to devote their time to raising them. Of course, a parent has to work. 
Usually, it is better for the man to do so because women are more natural 
caregivers. If your mom was able to work, it was probably after you went to 
sleep or was sent to someone else or you were a child that could occupy 
your own time for hours and hours. This may be possible for older kids, but 
not very young children. A woman who works cannot provide as much time with 
the child as a woman who is a devoted stay-at-home mom. That is a fact. 
Unless she does the work when the child is sleeping or at school, the child 
is going to miss out. Children deserve to have someone that is always going 
to be there. If you work, that complicates this as not every company is 
understanding. There are other responsibilities.
comments.author: jstele

comments.text:
+jstele if you watch animal planet you can tell it is the women that goes 
hunting, lions, bears, spiders, and more it is always the female. Women 
arent even equally paid or respected in Korea so of course a woman who 
stays at home would be more respected since some woman who work are even 
looked down on. I know not everyone is able to look after their kids and 
work at the same time but there are many stay at home dads and women who 
still work and take care of their kids. Isnt it better to have a other 
parent who goes out to work for their kid so they could pay for their 
college and stuff?﻿ Who says that if a mom works the kid cant have a stable 
environment? Things like that are mostly stereotypes and doubts by old 
fashioned people
comments.author: kuroichan101

comments.text:
+kuroichan101 Well, then you would be guessing wrong. I know there a lots 
of kids who have working mothers who would prefer it the other way. In 
Korea, the stay-at-home mother is more respected than in America, where 
some feel that it is anti-feminist. Not everyone is able to work and look 
after their child at the same time. Kids can be a distraction. In nature, 
it is the men who are the hunter/gatherers. The female usually stays with 
the children. Even in Korea, a lot of women do work, so it's not like there 
is an overwhelming pressure to quit. I would say that it is more of a 
choice than in America where you are more harshly judged for staying at 
home. Children need a stable environment.
